Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 04:09AM Dad5309 wrote: We had our meeting with the Breast Surgeon yesterday to discuss the pathology reports.  I figure I will switch to the IDC forum for the many questions I have, but wanted to let you know that there was not much good news.  He did a breast exam (has 30 years experience) and feels 3 lumps now and "at least 5 lymph nodes".  Also the biopsies were ER and PR minus and a high grade in all four of them (some good news somewhere would have been nice - instead of 1-3 they go 1-9 and I think three were 9s).  So of course he says mastectomy, then chemo, then maybe rads.  Doesn't sound like the whole body integrated care I was hoping for in a 'breast clinic'.  Sounds like each doctor does their thing and passes the patient off.  The nurse is your guide through the whole mess but you know how managed care is for - If you want to see your "primary care manager" good luck.  Take who is available or wait a month usually.  She has not seen the same PCM twice that I can recall.  And as the final kick in the face he said doing a bilateral M should be up to us - he says it is not medically necessary to remove other side.  Wait the final kick in the face was "can you tell us if you want a bilateral M by Friday so we can schedule surgery.  I see - we wait 2 weeks to see the breast surgeon and now you want life altering decision now with in my mind not all info.  How can woman be asked to make this decision so quickly and I can't believe with no mental health person to help.  And why should we make a decision not knowing if it has spread outside the breast?  That seems real relevant to me at this point.  At a minimum I would think you could be in a positive frame of mind going into surgery if you knew it had not spread outside the breast.   Thanks for the previous help everyone.
